alert.note: Alert for South Central Oregon Coast (Oregon) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Medford (Southwest Oregon and Northern California)
info.headline: Coastal Flood Watch issued January 02 at 4:41AM PST until January 03 at 5:00PM PST by NWS Medford
info.description: ...HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 4 PM THIS AFTERNOON TO 10 AM PST TUESDAY... ...COASTAL FLOOD WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM MONDAY MORNING THROUGH MONDAY AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Large breaking waves of 22 to 25 feet expected. High water levels around bays and estuaries are possible. * WHERE...High surf is expected along the south central Oregon coastline, but mainly along more south-facing shorelines. Coastal flooding may impact shorelines and waterfronts around tidal basins in Coos County, including North Bend, Coos Bay, and the areas and roads adjacent to sloughs and creeks, including Highways 42 and 101. * WHEN...The High Surf Advisory is in effect from 4 PM Sunday to 10 AM PST Tuesday. The Coastal Flood Watch is in effect from Monday morning through Monday afternoon. * IMPACTS...Large breaking waves will create hazardous conditions along and within the surf zone, and could inundate beaches and low lying shorelines. Beach erosion is possible. High water levels along bays and shorelines may result in lane closure or complete road closure. Low lying property and infrastructure along area tidal basins, including railroads, could become inundated. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS...High water levels resulting from King Tides, heavy rainfall, and storm force winds are expected to surpass thresholds that have caused minor flooding and road/lane closures in the past, particularly in the Coos Bay area. * View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
info.instruction: If travel is required, allow extra time as some roads may be closed. Do not drive around barricades or through water of unknown depth. Take the necessary actions to protect flood-prone property. Stay away from the surf zone and off of jetties. Area beaches may become hazardous due to dangerous surf conditions.
